awd_abstract_narration:
Robotics is at the forefront of technologies that rely on point cloud data produced by 3D sensors, such as stereo, structured light, time-of-light, light detection, and ranging. The 3D representation of the environment provided by these sensors can facilitate robotic tasks such as object detection, pose estimation, motion planning, grasping, and more. In contrast to other data modalities, working with 3D point clouds poses several significant challenges due to the presence of artifacts, non-uniform noise, and variation in density.  Robust real-time robotic applications have yet to be reliably achieved due to the complications of processing 3D point cloud data. Moreover, research on 3D point cloud processing has focused on extracting geometric features while ignoring the topological aspects of the data. Understanding the topology of the data is important to overcoming these limitations. This research lays the foundation for understanding the function of topological information obtained from diverse sensor data and advancing applications that are central to robotic perception.

This proposal seeks to enhance the capabilities of perception systems used in robotics applications by developing a framework that can extract topological features from 3D point cloud data. The crux of the proposal relies on using persistent homology to study topological features, such as connected components, holes, and voids, at multiple scales.  The research plan includes the design of algorithms and data structures along with robotic perception experiments evaluating these concepts. Specifically, this research will (i) provide fundamental insights into the role of persistent homology for handling 3D point clouds, (ii) design advanced algorithms and data structures for obtaining topological features from 3D sensor data, (iii) determine how topological persistence can complement existing geometric approaches for improving 3D point cloud processing, and (iv)  explore new avenues of robotic perception skills that make use of agile, robust, and stable topological data analysis of 3D point clouds. In doing so, this project has the potential to significantly improve the perceptual capabilities of robots. An open source library consisting of software developed for this project will be publicly released for educational and research purposes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
3D point cloud data is becoming increasingly abundant due to the availability of low-cost sensors. For example, light detection and ranging, stereo, structured light, and time-of-flight are sensors that can capture a 3D description of the surrounding environment. However, as 3D sensor technology becomes pervasive in robotics, modern approaches to process and make use of this data in innovative and meaningful ways has not kept up. The nature of point cloud datasets (noisy, sparse, and unorganized) requires fundamentally different processing models for extracting information. Robot perception applications making use of 3D point clouds such as navigation, object detection and classification, manipulation, etc., continue to be limited in reliability, efficiency, and scalability.

Topological data analysis refers to a collection of tools for extracting topology-based features from data. The main tool, persistent homology, allows us to study homology (i.e., connected components, holes, and voids) at multiple scales. In particular, it provides a basis to quantify the evolution of the homology of a parameterized family of topological spaces. For instance, we can study the persistent homology of a distance-varying region of a 3D point cloud by tracking the homological changes that occur as the distance parameter varies. Changes in topological features over a range of spatial resolutions can provide intuition on identifying important details from the noise. The overall goal of the project was to understand how the addition of topological information can yield unique insight into the structure of point cloud data.

We introduced a reinforcement learning approach that utilizes a novel and generalizable topology-based information gain metric for directing the next best view (i.e., a series of updated sensor placements) of a noisy 3D sensor. The metric combined the disjoint sections of an observed 3D surface to focus on high-detail features such as holes and concave sections. Experimental results showed that our method aids in establishing the placement of a robotic sensor to optimize the information provided by streaming point cloud data. The main insight obtained by this effort was that the incorporation of topological attributes can yield unique knowledge with respect to the structure of point cloud data, which is not obtainable from other metrics.

This project has created new topological algorithms and data structures to advance robot perception tasks. To date, the project has produced one peer-reviewed publication, with further papers in development. A labeled dataset of 3D objects, a CAD design for a custom robotic manipulator, and software for the transformation, union, and registration of point clouds has been made publicly available. Several graduate and undergraduate students, including underrepresented students, were trained in algorithmic development, experimental design, and persistent homology theory.
